articles.headline: The Year Chatbots Were Tamed
articles.snippet: A year ago, a rogue A.I. tried to break up my marriage. Did the backlash help make chatbots too boring?
articles.abstract: A year ago, a rogue A.I. tried to break up my marriage. Did the backlash help make chatbots too boring?
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago, on Valentine’s Day, I said good night to my wife, went to my home office to answer some emails and accidentally had the strangest first date of my life.

articles.headline: House Republican Majority Shrinks Again as Congress Faces Critical Issues
articles.snippet: The victory of Tom Suozzi, a Democrat, in a special election in New York will chip away at the already thin Republican hold over the House.
articles.abstract: The victory of Tom Suozzi, a Democrat, in a special election in New York will chip away at the already thin Republican hold over the House.

articles.headline: Booksellers on the Seine in Paris Get an Olympic Reprieve
articles.snippet: The French president’s decision avoided a standoff and brought relief to the sellers who have long operated in the heart of the capital.
articles.abstract: The French president’s decision avoided a standoff and brought relief to the sellers who have long operated in the heart of the capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gold-leafed books with engravings, 200-year-old leather-bound books, books so rare and precious they are wrapped carefully in cellophane before being nestled into place inside an antique wooden box set on the Seine’s stony shoulder for students, intellectuals, power brokers and tourists to browse.

articles.headline: Hundreds Flee One of Gaza’s Last Working Hospitals, Fearing Israeli Attack
articles.snippet: Israeli forces have been expanding their operations in the southern Gaza city of Khan Younis for weeks, and on Wednesday called for civilians at a hospital there to leave for “safer spaces.”
articles.abstract: Israeli forces have been expanding their operations in the southern Gaza city of Khan Younis for weeks, and on Wednesday called for civilians at a hospital there to leave for “safer spaces.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of displaced Palestinians fled one of the Gaza Strip’s last functioning hospitals on Wednesday, after the Israeli military ordered them to leave and threatened further action to stop what it said was Hamas activity there.
articles.byline: By Raja Abdulrahim, Nick Cumming-Bruce and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: What a Viral Post on Giraffes Says About China’s Fed-Up Investors
articles.snippet: As their losses pile up, Chinese investors are losing confidence not only in the stock market but in the government’s ability to turn the economy around.
articles.abstract: As their losses pile up, Chinese investors are losing confidence not only in the stock market but in the government’s ability to turn the economy around.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like many Chinese people, Jacky hoped that he could make enough money investing in China’s stock markets to help pay for an apartment in a big city. But in 2015 he lost $30,000, and in 2021 he lost $80,000. After that, he shut down his trading account and started investing in Chinese funds that track stocks in the United States.

articles.headline: Tesla’s Chair Under Scrutiny for Oversight of Elon Musk
articles.snippet: Robyn Denholm, who has led the electric car company’s board for more than five years, has been criticized for not serving as a check on Mr. Musk.
articles.abstract: Robyn Denholm, who has led the electric car company’s board for more than five years, has been criticized for not serving as a check on Mr. Musk.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the chief executive and public face of Tesla, is constantly making news and broadcasting his opinions on his social media site, X. But the electric car company has another leader — one who maintains a much lower profile.
articles.byline: By Natasha Frost and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Trump’s NATO Threat Reflects a Wider Shift on America’s Place in the World
articles.snippet: Alliances that were once seen as the bulwark of the Cold War are now viewed as an outdated albatross by a significant segment of the American public.
articles.abstract: Alliances that were once seen as the bulwark of the Cold War are now viewed as an outdated albatross by a significant segment of the American public.
articles.lead_paragraph: When former President Donald J. Trump told a campaign rally in South Carolina last weekend that he would encourage Russia to attack NATO allies who “didn’t pay,” there were gasps of shock in Washington, London, Paris, Tokyo and elsewhere around the world.

articles.headline: Japan’s Economy Slips Into Recession and to No. 4 in Global Ranking
articles.snippet: A slowdown in consumer and business spending held Japan back at the end of last year, with the economy contracting for the second straight quarter.
articles.abstract: A slowdown in consumer and business spending held Japan back at the end of last year, with the economy contracting for the second straight quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Japanese economy contracted at the end of last year, defying expectations for modest growth and pushing the country into a recession.
articles.byline: By Hisako Ueno and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: California’s Push for Ethnic Studies Runs Into the Israel-Hamas War
articles.snippet: The state’s high school students will be required to take the subject, but some object to how the discipline addresses the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
articles.abstract: The state’s high school students will be required to take the subject, but some object to how the discipline addresses the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: California has grand ambitions for ethnic studies. By 2025, the state’s public high schools — about 1,600 of them — must teach the subject. By 2030, students won’t be able to graduate high school without it.

articles.headline: Biden Faces More Pressure From Environmentalists to Block Steel Merger
articles.snippet: Climate change joins national security and concern about jobs in a mounting pressure campaign to prevent Nippon Steel from buying U.S. Steel.
articles.abstract: Climate change joins national security and concern about jobs in a mounting pressure campaign to prevent Nippon Steel from buying U.S. Steel.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden is facing new pressure to block Nippon Steel’s acquisition of the iconic manufacturer U.S. Steel, this time from environmental groups that say the tie-up would set back America’s efforts to curb climate change.

articles.headline: Airbus Pulls Further Ahead of Boeing in Global Plane Rivalry
articles.snippet: The European aerospace giant said it would deliver 800 planes this year, including its A320neo, which competes with Boeing’s troubled 737 Max. Airbus also announced progress on a new, more fuel-efficient aircraft.
articles.abstract: The European aerospace giant said it would deliver 800 planes this year, including its A320neo, which competes with Boeing’s troubled 737 Max. Airbus also announced progress on a new, more fuel-efficient aircraft.
articles.lead_paragraph: Airbus said Thursday that it would ramp up deliveries this year of some of the world’s most sought-after aircraft, bolstering its position as the largest plane maker and pulling further ahead of Boeing as its U.S. rival focuses on the fallout from a major safety crisis involving its 737 Max line of airliners.
